subject: Japanese Corporate Services Price Index (Apr) Y/Y 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.6%)
RBA adds AUD 1.29bln to the banking system through repos vs. Prev. AUD 726mln
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Mid-cap Japanese earnings, Japan PM Abe formally announced to lift the nationwide state of emergency
content:
AUSTRALIA

ANZ Bank (ANZ AT) - Co. CEO Elliot said they are considering reducing the size of business in China amid deterioration of relationship between Australia and China. (Newswires)

Coca-Cola Amatil (CCL AT) - Co. noted stringent lockdown measures in April adversely impacted the peak Easter, ANZAC Day and Ramadan trading period, while it noted that April volume fell about 33% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Coles Group (CGJ AT) - Co. will end all restrictions regarding purchases of grocery items. (Newswires)

Downer EDI (DOW AT) - Alsco is said to be expressing interest in Co.’s Spotless Laundries unit. (AFR)

Fortescue Metals (FMG AT) - Co. withdraws legal case against Argus related to publication of iron ore price information. (Newswires)

Senex Energy (SXY AT) - Co. in natural gas supply agreement with GLNG, while it raised FY20 output guidance to 2.0mln-2.1mln BOE from 1.8mln-2.0mln BOE. (Newswires)

Trade - China customs data from 2019 reportedly shows some products from Australia have history of import violations. (SCMP)

Other News - Australian PM Morrison is expected to comment on the government’s economic plan later today at the National Press Club of Australia at 0330BST. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Asahi Co. (3333 JP) - Co. is to borrow JPY 1.185tln from SMBC to acquire AB InBev’s (ABI BB) Australia unit. (Newswires)

Fujifilm (4901 JT) - Japan government reportedly gives up on trying to approve Co.’s Avigan drug for COVID-19 treatment by end-May. (Kyodo)

Fujikura (5803 JT) - Co. cuts FY net forecast to loss of JPY 33bln from prev. forecast of JPY 7.5bln loss. (Newswires)

H20 Retailing (8242 JT) - Co. FY net loss JPY 13.2bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 2.2bln Y/Y, recognized JPY 14.2bln impairment on restructuring. (Newswires)

Hitachi Chemical (4217 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 16.4bln vs. Prev. JPY 28.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Japan Steel Works (5631 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 9.3bln vs. Prev. JPY 19.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

NGK Spark Plug (5334 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 30.1bln vs. Prev. JPY 42.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. and Renault reportedly dropped plans to push for a merger and instead will work to fix their alliance, according to sources. (Newswires) 

Sharp (6753 JT) - S&P cut Outlook from Stable to Negative, Affirmed Rating at BB-. (Newswires)

Shimamura (8227 JT) - Co. May same store sales fell 23.4% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese PM Abe formally lifted the nationwide State of Emergency, while he stated that the combined economic stimulus from the 1st & 2nd economic packages will be above JPY 200tln and that they will decide on the 2nd budget on Wednesday. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Korean Air Lines (003490 KS) - Co. is to offer KRW 300bln of new shares as collateral for additional financial support. (Yonhap)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. share of global NAND market in Q1 declined to 33.3% which was down by 2.2ppts from the prior quarter. (Yonhap)

Other News - South Korea and China are to discuss widening the scope for their free trade agreement to better cover service and investment sectors. (Yonhap)

subject: Australian ANZ Roy Morgan Consumer Confidence W/W 92.7 (Prev. 92.3)
RBA says excess cash at exchange settlement accounts at AUD 51.9bln vs. Prev.  AUD 50.7bln
Japan government reportedly gives up on trying to approve Fujifilm's (4901 JT) Avigan drug for COVID-19 treatment by end-May
Canadian PM Trudeau says his government is trying to provide 10 days sick pay per year as the country prepares for a possible 2nd wave of coronavirus
China customs data from 2019 reportedly shows some products from Australia have history of import violations
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR IS NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include: New Zealand Trade Data, Singapore Q1 Final GDP, Industrial Production and CPI
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

WHO temporarily suspended hydroxychloroquine in its COVID19 'solidarity trials' pending safety data, while it will study potential harms and benefits. (Newswires)

Novavax said it begun enrolling participants for its first human study of its COVID19 vaccine candidate in Australia and that if initial results are promising, it plans to conduct phase 2 of the study across multiple countries including the US. (WSJ)

US CDC reports coronavirus cases rose by 15,342 to a total of 1,637,456 and the death toll rose by 620 to 97,699, (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose by 112 to 36,914 vs. Prev. increase of 118 and the case count rose by 1,625 vs. Prev. increase of 2,409. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Chinese Foreign Ministry said China will take necessary countermeasures if US insists on undermining China's interests in regards to Hong Kong related sanctions. (Newswires)

Chinese companies listed in US have started seeking listings in Hong Kong and mainland China, which they will speed up doing as China-US relations sour, while regulators are likely to launch reforms to accelerate the trend according to experts. (Global Times)

Japanese PM Abe formally lifted the nationwide State of Emergency, while he stated that the combined economic stimulus from the 1st & 2nd economic packages will be above JPY 200tln and that they will decide on the 2nd budget on Wednesday. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said the government plans to allow car showrooms and outdoor markets to reopen from June 1st and will allow all non-essential retail to open from June 15th, while he added that he hopes the UK economy will bounce back in the coming months. (Newswires)

Eurogroup chief Centeno said EU deputy finance ministers have found common ground on the details of the EIB’s pan European guarantee fund which paves the way for a formal approval by the EIB board tomorrow, while he added that it is well on track to become operational by June 1st. (Newswires)

ECB’s Villeroy said the ECB will very probably need to go even further and will not allow unwarranted rate hikes in some nations, while he added that the ECB is clearly prepared to exceed its inflation target. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

Russian President Putin spoke with the Iraqi PM and expressed support for the OPEC+ deal, as well as the importance of continued joint efforts in the oil market, according to the Kremlin. (Newswires)

Russia is to impose a temporary ban on oil product imports, while there were separate reports that Russian gas transit via the Yamal-Europe pipeline has almost dried up, according to Interfax citing transport operators. (Interfax)

Russian Energy Ministry sees global oil demand recovering in May and considers oil market supply to have fallen by 14mln-15mln BPD. Furthermore, it sees the global oil market in balance by June-July and sees current market global surplus at between 7-12mln BPD (prev. 20-30mln BPD), according to sources. (RIA)

India Minister said they are exploring the possibility in the US to store low-priced crude oil and have urged the finance ministry to cut some oil producer taxes. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

US markets were shut, although European bourses kicked the week off on the front-foot in holiday-thinned trade, after taking a positive lead from Asia. In the absence of UK and US participants, European indices initially eked out mild gains but sentiment picked up in recent trade (Eurostoxx 50 +1.1%) in spite of lingering tensions between US and China and ongoing concerns about an impending clash regarding the EU recovery fund with sentiment instead potentially lifted by a pick-up in reopening efforts across the continent. Sectors are higher across the board with outperformance seen in IT and industrial names, with performance for the latter bolstered by German heavyweight Bayer (+6.9%) after the Co. reportedly reached a verbal agreement regarding 50-85k of the 125k US Roundup lawsuits. Elsewhere, individual movers include Lagardere (+11.8%) with Co. shares boosted after French billionaire Arnault agreed to buy a stake in the Co., whilst Deutsche Lufthansa (+2.0%) shares have been supported amid ongoing hopes that the Co. can strike a deal with the German government and reports that the airline will resume more flights as of mid-June; something which has also provided a tailwind in the travel-space for Tui (+11.3%). Elsewhere, gains of over 2% for Renault were faded early doors (currently +1.1%) with the Co. and Nissan set to announce billions of USD in cost cutting measures this week, according to sources. Note, competitor Peugeot (+2.8%) has managed to maintain strength in early European trade as markets await details of support measures for the French auto sector that are due to be announced tomorrow.

subject: SERVICE NOTICE: Service has now concluded until APAC session (2200 BST/1700 EDT); due to UK Bank Holiday and US Memorial Day holiday, the desk will shut early today; desk hours and market closure times included
content:
NEWSQUAWK SERVICE:

  • On Sunday May 24th the Asia-Pacific service will open at its regular time of 2200BST/1600CDT with the European service also opening at its regular time of 0630BST/0030CDT on Monday 25th May given that European markets will be open for trade.
  • The European service will run to 1800BST, upon which the desk will close. Note, there will be no US service thereafter for that session due to US market closures.
  • The service will then re-open later that evening on May 25th at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pacific session with full coverage to resume thereafter on Tuesday May 26th.

MARKET CLOSURES (NYSE holiday schedule here; CME/NYMEX here; CBOE here):

  • UK: All UK products are closed on Monday.
  • EUROPE: Regular close and trading on Monday
  • US FLOOR TRADE: Friday 22nd May 2020 early close at 1200CDT/1800BST; closed on Monday 25th May 2020
  • US ELECTRONIC TRADE (Monday 25th May): Equity products close 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST; interest rate products close 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST; FX closed 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST; NYMEX closed 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST

subject: UK COVID-19 death toll rises 112 to 36,914 (Prev. +118 to 36,793); Case count rises 1,625 (prev. 2,409)

Regeneron (REGN) announces offering of common stock held by Sanofi (SAN FP) and USD 5bln stock repurchase; Sanofi to sell its equity stake in Regeneron, says there will be no changes to ongoing collaboration
Eurogroup chief Centeno says EU deputy finance ministers have found common ground on the details of the EIB’s paneuropean guarantee fund, paves the way for a formal approval by the EIB board tomorrow
content: • Adds: is well on track to become operational by June 1

subject: WHO to temporarily suspend hydrochloroquine in its COVID19 'solidarity trials', pending safety data; says it will study potential harms and benefits
EUROPEAN PRELIMINARY CASH EQUITY CLOSES: EURO STOXX 50 (+2.25%) at 2971, DAX (+2.80%) at 11384, CAC 40 (+2.15%) at 4540, IBEX 35 (+2.40%) at 6858, FTSE MIB (+1.58%) at 17,591, SMI (+1.54%) at 9838
Canada COVID-19 death toll rises to 6,453 (prev. 6,380), cases rise to 85,103 (prev. 84,081)
German European Affairs Minister Roth says there are no signs the UK will seek a Brexit discussions extension
Deutsche Lufthansa (LHA GY) - Economic Stabilization Fund approves up to EUR 9bln of aid; German government will now have two seats on the supervisory board
content: • WSF will have a silent stake valued at EUR 4.7bln

subject: Tencent proposes to conduct an international debt offering - Co currently has USD 12bln of outstanding notes
Russian energy ministry sees global market in balance by June-July, according to a source cited by RIA; sees current market global surplus at between 7-12mln BPD (prev. 20-30mln BPD)
ECB APP: PSPP EUR +9.545bln (Prev. EUR +10.936bln), CSPP EUR +1.181bln (Prev. EUR +2.324bln), CBPP3 EUR +1.082bln (Prev. EUR +1.03bln), ABSPP EUR -0.377bln (Prev. EUR +0.161bln)
ECB PEPP EUR +30.072bln (w/e May 22) vs. Prev. EUR +28.878bln a week earlier
German labour union Verdi says it is cancelling wage contract with Deutsche Post (DPW GY), effective August 31st

Russian Energy Ministry sees global oil demand recovering in May; considers oil market supply to have fallen by 14-15mln BPD; sees non-OPEC+ countries to have already cut output by 3.5-4mln BPD, according to RIA citing sources

EU regulators to investigate Air Canada bid for Canadian tour operator Transat; says deal may reduce competition in air transport services between Canada and Europe; decision due before 30th September

Russian Urals oil exports from Baltic ports are set at 4.4mln T in June (prev. 4.3mln T in May plan); Urals and Siberian Light oil loadings from Novorossiisk set at 1.28mln T in June (prev. 1.12 T in May) - according to a schedule
Brazilian Central Bank says banks have deferred BRL 535.7bln in loan repayments from March 16th to May 15th
Russian gas transit via the Yamal-Europe pipeline has almost dried up, according to Interfax citing transport operators
Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM) is expected to give a conditional green light on Tuesday for a state-backed loan for Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM), according to a source
India Minister says it is exploring the possibility in the US to store low-priced crude oil; says oil ministry urged the finance ministry to cut some oil producer taxes
Mexican President Obrador says the reduction in China's economic output creates opportunity for more investment to come into Mexico
Israel PM Netanyahu says he will not let the opportunity to annex the West Bank pass, according to Israeli reporter
content: • Via Channel 13 reporter

subject: Daimler (DAI GY) says it is heading towards carbon-neutral production by 2022

Meituan Dianping says consumption is recovering faster in China's lower-tier cities than in the higher-tier ones; says daily food delivery volumes reached 90% of pre-pandemic levels during the week of May 11th
Germany seeks to raise Deutsche Bahn debt limit to EUR 30bln (from EUR 25bln), according to Spiegel
Russian President Putin spoke with the Iraqi PM and expressed support for the OPEC+ deal, as well as discussing the importance of continued joint efforts in the oil market, according to the Kremlin

German Chancellor Merkel told senior party members that the government would not allow the EU to take some of Lufthansa's (LHA GY) takeoff and landing slots at Frankfurt and Munich away; said "we will not give in" on an aid package- Handelsblatt
UK government is preparing a statement to be made by adviser Dominic Cummings
German Economy Ministry spokesperson says talks between Lufthansa (LHA GY) and the government are in the end phase, but have not finished just yet
China Global Times notes rising sightings of China's new prototype fighter jet, FC-31, suggesting development is making smooth progress
content: • Via article

subject: Russia is to impose a temporary ban on oil product imports, according to Interfax
Russia is to impose a temporary ban on oil product imports, according to Interfax
Citi FX model favours USD selling into month-end
content:
• Citi says that after months of elevated asset-price volatility, May saw relatively small moves in FX and bonds; equities gain (+2.4% for MSCI US), while major government bonds have declined in local currency terms.
  • The signal to sell is driven by equity investor rebalancing needs, Citi says, as gains in equities has likely left them underhedged.

subject: German Labour Agency forecasts a 2020 deficit of EUR 30.5bln, 2021 deficit EUR 4.4bln, 2022 deficit of EUR 1.3bln; Handelsblatt report
content: • Link to Article

subject: Lufthansa (LHA GY) - German Economy Minister reiterates that discussions are now at an advanced stage regarding a rescue package
Lufthansa (LHA GY) - Co. and the German Gov't have reportedly agreed on a rescue package, Focus Online; Gov't wants to ease some contact restrictions from June 6th
content:
• Reportedly agreed on billions in Gov't aid for the Co; however, state economic stabilisation fund steering bodies and the EU Commission are yet to agree
  • Link to Article
reaction_details: • In a delayed reaction, as the news got a wider airing across business TV, Co. shares extended on initial upside and currently trade with gains in excess of 4% on the day
analysis_details: • Follows pre-market reports that the EUR 9bln bailout from Germany is reportedly being delayed by efforts to ensure the scheme will be approved quickly by the EU; talks are ongoing over a timetable for Germany to exit from a direct stake in the Co

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Choppy waters amid thin trade and light news-flow - 25th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

In holiday-thinned trade, European bourses have kicked the week off on the front-foot after taking a positive lead from Asia. In the absence of UK and US participants, European indices initially eked out mild gains but sentiment picked up in recent trade (Eurostoxx 50 +1.1%) in spite of lingering tensions between US and China and ongoing concerns about an impending clash regarding the EU recovery fund with sentiment instead potentially lifted by a pick-up in reopening efforts across the continent. Sectors are higher across the board with outperformance seen in IT and industrial names, with performance for the latter bolstered by German heavyweight Bayer (+6.9%) after the Co. reportedly reached a verbal agreement regarding 50-85k of the 125k US Roundup lawsuits. Elsewhere, individual movers include Lagardere (+11.8%) with Co. shares boosted after French billionaire Arnault agreed to buy a stake in the Co., whilst Deutsche Lufthansa (+2.0%) shares have been supported amid ongoing hopes that the Co. can strike a deal with the German government and reports that the airline will resume more flights as of mid-June; something which has also provided a tailwind in the travel-space for Tui (+11.3%). Elsewhere, gains of over 2% for Renault were faded early doors (currently +1.1%) with the Co. and Nissan set to announce billions of USD in cost cutting measures this week, according to sources. Note, competitor Peugeot (+2.8%) has managed to maintain strength in early European trade as markets await details of support measures for the French auto sector that are due to be announced tomorrow.

FX                                                                                     

EUR, CHF - The G10 underperformers thus far in holiday-thinned volumes as the Single Currency eyes a roadblock regarding the EU Recovery Fund – with the “frugal four” (Austria, Denmark, Netherlands, and Sweden) countering the Franco-German proposal of grant distributions. The perceived hawks call for loan allocations – a drawback for peripheries Italy, Spain, and Greece (among others) – with the former also facing a potential rise in domestic anti-Euro sentiment. EUR/USD breached Friday’s 1.0885 low which coincide with the 10DMA to a current low of 1.0871, having briefly dipped below its 21DMA at 1.0873. Further levels to the downside include a Fib at 1.0864 (61.8% of the 1.0775-1.1008 move) ahead of the psychological 1.0850. Unrevised German GDP finals and an overall mixed Ifo survey did little to shift the narrative. Option expiries see EUR 550mln at 1.0875-85, 800mln at 1.0895-1.0900, and EUR 1bln rolling off between 1.0910-20. The Franc meanwhile sees safe-haven outflows, albeit to a greater extent vs. its Japanese counterpart as EUR/CHF revisits support around the 1.0575 area.

DXY, CNY, HKD - The broader Dollar and Index initially extends on overnight gains before pulling back, with support also derived from the heavy EUR basket contribution. DXY inched higher towards 100.000 (vs. low 99.716) to the upside with its 50DMA residing nearby at 100.02. Elsewhere, the Yuan remains on the backfoot amid heightened US-Sino tensions, coupled with international backlash for Mainland’s crackdown on anti-govt Hong Kong behaviour. Further, the PBOC set the weakest CNY fixing since 2008 (7.1209 vs. Prev. 7.0939) following Friday’s losses. HKD meanwhile unsurprisingly experienced weakness but USD/HKD sees itself just above the bottom end of the 7.75-7.85 peg.

GBP, CAD - The marginally better performers ex-USD, but action remains minimal in thin conditions. Cable overnight remained restricted under 1.2200 as PM Johnson was said to face Cabinet revolt after supporting senior adviser Cummings who faced calls to resign after breaching the lockdown – potentially leading to Cabinet dissent and citizens disobeying lockdown rules. Brexit developments have also remained in focus amid the diminishing timeframe to hammer out an FTA by year-end. Weekend developments noted that the UK is in a fresh stand-off with the EU regarding delays in granting diplomatic status to the EU’s representation in London. Furthermore, relations with China should be watched over the Hong Kong developments – with PM Johnson reportedly looking to reduce Huawei’s involvement in UK 5G network within the next three years. Cable resides towards the bottom of the current 1.2162-91 intraday band, ahead of a 61.8% Fib of last week’s bounce coinciding with Friday’s low ~1.2160. The Loonie meanwhile tracks price action in the US energy benchmarks. USD/CAD resides just south of 1.4000, having earlier tested resistance at its 21DMA at 1.4007 (intraday high).

AUD, NZD - Antipodeans tracked the weakness in the Yuan as tensions with China remain elevated and with the US-Sino spat also providing less basis to join in on global lockdown easing optimism/vaccine hopes. AUD/USD drifted off session lows ~0.6520 (vs. high 0.6550) amid a pullback in the DXY, with the 100 and 21DMAs both residing at 0.6490. The Kiwi meanwhile fares modestly worse as the AUD/NZD cross found a current base at 1.0700. NZD/USD meanwhile sees itself just under 0.6100 (vs. high 0.6108) but threatening Friday’s low at 0.6079.

JPY - Modest losses for the Japanese currency, albeit more-so a function of the firmer Buck. Reports noted that Japan is to lift the state of emergency declaration in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Hokkaido today. USD/JPY sees itself hovering on either side of its 55 DMA (107.71) vs. its overnight low at 107.54 and ahead of its 50 DMA at 107.91..

FIXED INCOME

Given the market closures, in both the UK and US today, the schedule is unsurprisingly light and price action has for the most part has been rangebound. Core counterparts started the week off firmer as protest action ramped up in Hong Kong in protest to the proposed national security law with an analysis piece available for this on Newsquawk headline feed. Aside from this, newsflow has been relatively sparse aside from the German Ifo survey which came in slightly mixed, with 2/3 measures beating expectations and was accompanied by, relatively speaking, cautiously optimistic commentary for some sectors ahead. However, this release did nothing to spur price action in the Bund which has been gradually relinquishing the mild early-doors bid since the European cash open as sentiment has slowly improved. Trade which has seen the core EU debt measure remain within a narrow 25-tick range so far (172.98-173.28). Price action within the periphery is similarly contained as focus moves to Wednesday’s presentation of the European recovery package, which is already under threat via an alternative proposal from the ‘frugal four’ which would provide loans not grants; and therefore, likely place substantially pressure on the finances of areas including Italy and Spain. Finally, USTs are essentially flat, with no cash trade state-side, and futures having seen a pullback similar to their EU peer; focus for the US this week is on the PCE and GDP prints.

COMMODITIES 

WTI and Brent front month futures see mild gains in early trade with traded volumes on the lighter side amid absences from UK and US markets/participants; while fresh fundamental news flow remains light. Eyes remain on the wider implications on global trade and sentiment from the fallout of the US-Sino trade spat threatening a cold war, whilst investors must not be distraction from the prospects of reinstated lockdowns should COVID-19 cases rise again. On Friday, the Baker Hughes rig count printed another decline in active rigs, whilst OPEC Secretary General Barkindo posited tentative signs of recovery and we believe the worst is behind us. WTI July meanders around USD 33.50/bbl (USD 32.50-33.75/bbl range), whilst Brent July sees itself oscillating between gains and losses, now residing north of USD 35/bbl (34.50-35.40 range). Spot gold moves in tandem to the Buck as sees itself with mild intraday losses around USD 1730/oz (USD 1724-35 band) whilst copper mimics price action in stocks to reclaim USD 2.40/lb to the upside.

subject: Japanese PM Abe wants to propose a patent pool at G7 meeting next month (around June 10th) in order for COVID-19 medicine and vaccines to be used in developing nations
Japanese PM Abe says the combined economic stimulus from the 1st & 2nd economic packages will be above JPY 200tln, will decide on 2nd budget on Wednesday
analysis_details: • Follows reports that, the Japan’s government is considering compiling a second supplementary budget valued more than JPY 100tln which will consist of JPY 60tln for interest loan scheme for businesses and JPY 27tln for other financial support measures. (Newswires)

subject: Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) - Owners of manipulated diesel cars from the Co. are entitled to damages payments, according to the German Federal Court
analysis_details: • Subsequently, Co. state they intend to offer one-off payments to individual plaintiffs relating to this

subject: Japanese PM Abe says the nationwide State of Emergency will be lifted today
analysis_details: • Earlier reports noted Japan is reportedly to lift the state of emergency declaration in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama and Hokkaido today. There were also comments from Japanese Economic Minister Nishimura that the emergency declaration is no longer needed in any of Japan's regions and the expert panel also agreed the state of emergency can be lifted for all areas. (Nikkei/Newswires)

subject: China's Commerce Minister, regarding duties on barley imports from Australia, says that the trade remedy measures have been both prudent and restrained
FX Morning Colour: Volumes oppressed; EUR repressed; DXY progresses
content:

subject: Japanese PM Abe has told the ruling LDP party that some restraints on inter-regional movements will be maintained until June 19th, according to Kyodo News
analysis_details:
• Japanese Economic Minister Nishimura says seeking expert opinion on ending state of emergency and notes that emergency declaration is no longer needed in any Japan's regions - follows press reports that Japan is to lift the state of emergency declaration in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama and Hokkaido today. 
  • Press announcement expected around 10:00BST today

subject: Nigeria Q1 oil output 2.07mln vs. Prev. 1.96mln YY
analysis_details: • Note this is stale given the OPEC+ pact implemented at the start of May

subject: Swiss Sight Deposits: Domestic banks CHF 596.632 (Prev. CHF 591.013bln); Total CHF 679.92bln (Prev. 673.494bln)

Germany are considering EUR 50,000 per month in support for medium-sized companies with up to 249 employees. Support will run from June-December and will have an initial cost of EUR 25bln, according to DPA
Chinese Foreign Ministry says China will take necessary countermeasures if US insists on undermining China's interests in regards to Hong-Kong related sanctions
analysis_details: • US National Security Adviser O’Brien stated that the US government will likely impose economic sanctions on Hong Kong and China if China moves forward with national security law for Hong Kong. There were also separate reports that US announced it will include 33 Chinese firms and institutions to an economic blacklist for actions including assisting Beijing spy on the minority Uighur population or allegations of ties to China's military and WMDs. (Newswires/NY Times)

subject: Movers: Tui AG (TUI1 GY) +4.1%, Bayer (BAYN GY) +4%, Peugeot (UG FP) +3.2%, Lagardere (MMB FP) +3%, Deutsche Lufthansa (LHA GY) +2.4%, Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) +2.1%, Renault (RNO FP) +2.1%, Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) +1.7%
Additional European Equity News
content:
Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. will not return to service its A380s as part of an EU anti-carbon agenda. Separately, Lufthansa (LHA GY) said the dispute over Airbus jet purchases is resolved but the agreement is still delayed. (Newswires) 

AB InBev (ABI BB) – Japan’s Asahi is to borrow JPY 1.185tln for the purchase of AB InBev’s Australian unit. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY) – Group is mulling designing its own software platform (Newswires)

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) - Italian Economy Minister said he was confident that the group will be able to reach a deal with the govt. (Newswires) 

Hong Kong exposed stocks - Over the weekend, protesters took to the streets to rally against the Mainland’s planned national security law. (Newswires)

Italian/Spanish stocks - Netherlands, Austria, Denmark, and Sweden have tabled an alternative proposal for the EU recovery fund that would have a two-year limit and provide loans, not grants. (FT)

Kuehne + Nagel (KNIN SW) - Co. could cut over 20k jobs, according to its majority shareholder. (Newswires) 

Lagardere (MMB FP) – Lagardere & Arnault families have agreed to a partnership, which will see Arnault, owner of LVMH (MC FP), holding a stake equivalent to ¼ of Lagardere Capital Management share capital; regulator declarations will occur on completion. (Newswires)

Metso (METSO FH) – COVID-19 will adversely impact the short-term business of Neles. Mid-term (2025) targets for Neles are: orders received over EUR 1bln, EBITA margin above 15%, dividend payout of circa 40% net earnings. (Newswires)

PSA (UG FP)/ Renault (RNO FP) - French Finance Minister Le Maire said President Macron will tomorrow announce "strong" measures to aid the auto sector. (Newswires) 

Renault (RNO FP) - French Finance Minister Le Maire said raising stake in Co. is not on the agenda for now. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) - German federal court is to deliver ruling in a case of which a van owner is seeking damages for being sold a diesel manipulated engine. (Newswires)

subject: ANALYSIS: Hong Kong protests could morph into a global issue
content:
OVERVIEW: Over the weekend, protesters took to the streets to rally against the Mainland’s planned national security law – effectively banning all activities aimed at toppling the central government and the influence on Hong Kong affairs. Multiple rounds of tear gas were fired by Hong Kong police whilst water cannons were used to deter congregations of protesters.

WIDER IMPLICATIONS: The National Security law has been met with a raft of resistance from 23 countries, who all issued a statement calling it “comprehensive assault on the city’s autonomy, rule of law and fundamental freedoms”.

  • US REACTION: US National Security Adviser O’Brien stated that the US government will likely impose economic sanctions on Hong Kong and China if China moves forward with national security law for Hong Kong. This would see Hong Kong’s special status removed that allowed it to function as an international financial hub.
  • EU REACTION: The EU urged China to respect Hong Kong’s autonomy and the ‘One Country Two Systems’ principle and said it “considers that democratic debate, consultation of key stakeholders, and respect for protected rights and freedoms in Hong Kong would represent the best way of proceeding with the adoption of national security legislation”, whilst stating developments will be followed closely. Meanwhile, Hong Kong protests leader Joshua Wong said he wants the EU to impose sanctions on Chinese politicians over the law.
  • UK REACTION: UK handed Hong Kong back to China in 1997 under a 50yr agreement to the “one country, two systems” governance. Some believe Britain has too much at stake to confront China over Hong Kong; on this, new legal advice suggests the UK could open its doors to Hong Kong citizens. Meanwhile, Telegraph said PM Johnson was reportedly planning to reduce Huawei’s involvement in the UK 5G network within the next three years.

subject: NOTICE: Due to the upcoming UK bank holiday and US Memorial Day holiday on Monday 25th May, the desk will be running a reduced service alongside the subsequent market closures
content:
NEWSQUAWK SERVICE:

  • On Sunday May 24th the Asia-Pacific service will open at its regular time of 2200BST/1600CDT with the European service also opening at its regular time of 0630BST/0030CDT on Monday 25th May given that European markets will be open for trade.
  • The European service will run to 1800BST, upon which the desk will close. Note, there will be no US service thereafter for that session due to US market closures.
  • The service will then re-open later that evening on May 25th at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pacific session with full coverage to resume thereafter on Tuesday May 26th.

MARKET CLOSURES (NYSE holiday schedule here; CME/NYMEX here; CBOE here):

  • UK: All UK products are closed on Monday.
  • EUROPE: Regular close and trading on Monday
  • US FLOOR TRADE: Friday 22nd May 2020 early close at 1200CDT/1800BST; closed on Monday 25th May 2020
  • US ELECTRONIC TRADE (Monday 25th May): Equity products close 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST; interest rate products close 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST; FX closed 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST; NYMEX closed 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST

subject: Larger G10 FX option expiries for today's NY cut at 1500BST
Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
25 May 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real-time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly higher following last Friday’s recovery on Wall St. where the US major indices gradually clawed back opening losses after encouraging comments from NIH’s Fauci and US plans for large Phase 2 trials, spurred vaccine-related optimism. ASX 200 (+1.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.5%) traded positively with tech and energy front-running the broad gains seen across Australia’s sectors, while sentiment in Tokyo was underpinned by expectations the state of emergency will be lifted today in all remaining areas including the capital and with the government reportedly considering compiling a new package mostly consisting of financial support to companies which would be funded by a second supplementary budget valued more than JPY 100tln. Hang Seng (-1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) lagged their regional peers with the mainland bourse choppy amid ongoing US-China tensions and with the Hong Kong benchmark extending on last Friday’s near-6% slump after thousands of protesters rallied on Sunday against China’s national security law, while the protests were met heavy handed by the police which used pepper spray and a water cannon to disperse the crowd.

FTSE 100 – UK markets will be closed due to Late May Bank Holiday

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. are reportedly threatening to remove support to suppliers who do not comply with price cuts of as much as 15%. (FT)

Shell (RDSA LN) – CEO said it will limit raises for the next 18-months whilst seeking voluntary severance. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Aston Martin (AMT LN) – CEO Palmer is reportedly to leave according to sources, with Moers the CEO of Mercedes-Benz reportedly to replace him; announcement could be as soon as Tuesday. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

MARKS & SPENCER (MKS LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM SELL AT LIBERUM CAPITAL

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Co. has reportedly reached a verbal agreement regarding 50-85k of the 125k US Roundup lawsuits. The agreements are part of its USD 10bln move to conclude all claims, sources state. The group is likely to announce settlements in June. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. have asked hundreds of their top managers to forfeit a months pay given COVID-19. (FT)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – EUR 9bln bailout from Germany is reportedly being delayed by efforts to ensure the scheme will be approved quickly by the EU; talks are ongoing over a timetable for Germany to exit from a direct stake in the Co. Separately, Co. are to resume flights to 20 destinations as of mid-June. (Newswires/City AM)

Merck KGaA (MRK GY) – Co. said data demonstrate evobrutinib has a sustained and high impact on annualized relapse rate over 108 weeks. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. will not return to service its A380s as part of an EU anti-carbon agenda. (Newswires)

Renault (RNO FP) – Renault and Nissan (7201 JT) are reportedly to announce billions of USD in cost cutting measures this week according to sources, which would see Nissan cut capacity by a further 1mln vehicles, to 5.5mln. The announcement is be announced across Wednesday, Thursday & Friday. (WSJ) Separately, French Environment Minister said the group must stop producing capacity abroad in order to receive state support. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) – Co’s Dupixent Eosinophilic Esophagitis Phase III trial met both of its co-primary endpoints alongside all key secondary endpoints. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France-KLM (AF FP) – French Environment Minister said the group must reduce air traffic and agree to reduce Co2 emission of domestic flights by 50% by 2024 as part of its deal for state-aid. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM)/UBI Banca (UBI IM) – Italian press notes that Intesa’s offer for UBI Banca could be delayed until September. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI                 

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Nokia (NOKIA FH)/ Ericsson (ERICB SS) –UK PM Johnson is reportedly planning to reduce Huawei’s involvement in UK 5G network within the next three years. (FT/Telegraph)

Pandora (PNDORA DC) – Co. executive said the group is planning to reopen around half of its North American locations. (Newswires)

Tele2 (TELE2B SS) – Co. is to launch its first 5G network in June in Sweden. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US – Markets will be shut on account of Memorial Day Holiday

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.2% at 2,955, NDX +0.4% at 9,414, DJIA -0.0% at 24,465. SECTORS: Energy -0.6%, materials -0.2%, industrials -0.2%, consumer discretionary -0.2%, consumer staples +0.3%, healthcare +0.2%, financials -0.3%, IT +0.4%, telecoms +0.5%, utilities +1.1%

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 25th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·        Asian equity markets began the week mostly higher following last Friday’s recovery on Wall St. where the US major indices gradually clawed back opening losses

·        Thousands of protesters rallied in Hong Kong on Sunday against China’s national security law

·        US announced it will include 33 Chinese firms and institutions in an economic blacklist

·        The Oxford University COVID-19 vaccine has only around a 50% chance of success, according to the Professor leading the development of the drug

·        DXY was lacklustre with price action rangebound beneath the 100.00 level owing to the absence of key global markets

·        US administration officials reportedly held discussions on Friday about the possibility of conducting a nuclear test

·       Looking ahead, highlights include German GDP (detailed), German IFO. Note, today is a UK & US market holiday

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US CDC reported coronavirus cases rose by 26,229 to a total of 1,622,114 and death toll rose by 1,047 to a total of 97,049, while AFP tweeted that US coronavirus death toll rose by 638 citing the Johns Hopkins tracker. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that schools in the US should be opened ASAP and suggested there was plenty of very good information now available. In other news, the state of Nevada is setting June 4th as the reopening date for casinos. (Twitter/Newswires)

US will reportedly test experimental coronavirus vaccines in 100k people or more from July in which the vaccine candidate from Oxford University may be tested side by side with Moderna's (MRNA), while Johnson & Johnson, Merck and Sanofi vaccines could be added in summer. (Newswires) Other reports note, as a result of how quickly the virus is fading and the subsequent impact on testing samples, the Oxford University COVID-19 vaccine has only around a 50% chance of success, according to the Professor leading the development of the drug. (Telegraph)

US White House suspended travel to the US for foreigners that have visited Brazil in past 14 days. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson confirmed the UK will be in a position to move to step 2 of the plan and that reception, year 1 and year 6 students will return to school on June 1st, while he added we are making good progress although the progress is provisional. (Newswires)

China’s Global Times stated that a research team led by Peking University is taking the lead by unsheathing neutralizing antibodies, which will likely lay the foundation for potent treatment against the coronavirus and that it would hopefully be available as early as this winter. (Twitter)

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mostly higher following last Friday’s recovery on Wall St. where the US major indices gradually clawed back opening losses after encouraging comments from NIH’s Fauci and US plans for large Phase 2 trials, spurred vaccine-related optimism. ASX 200 (+1.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.5%) traded positively with tech and energy front-running the broad gains seen across Australia’s sectors, while sentiment in Tokyo was underpinned by expectations the state of emergency will be lifted today in all remaining areas including the capital and with the government reportedly considering compiling a new package mostly consisting of financial support to companies which would be funded by a second supplementary budget valued more than JPY 100tln. Hang Seng (-1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) lagged their regional peers with the mainland bourse choppy amid ongoing US-China tensions and with the Hong Kong benchmark extending on last Friday’s near-6% slump after thousands of protesters rallied on Sunday against China’s national security law, while the protests were met heavy handed by the police which used pepper spray and a water cannon to disperse the crowd. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally lower amid gains in Japanese stocks but with downside stemmed by the BoJ ‘s presence in the market for nearly JPY 1.1tln of JGBs mostly concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.1209 vs. Exp. 7.1205 (Prev. 7.0939)

Chinese President Xi said the country’s economy will prove resilient in the long term and that it will stand on the right side of history amid the rise of protectionism. There were also separate comments from the NDRC that it expects domestic consumption to show signs of an improvement this month as new forms of consumption such as e-commerce are encouraged. (SCMP/Newswires)

China State Council Research Office Director Huang said there was intense debate on whether to drop the GDP target for this year or not and that the final decision was made to free local governments from burden of a numeric target and to encourage them to focus on protecting jobs, livelihoods and small businesses. (Newswires)

China’s Global Times noted that Chinese experts predict the PBoC is highly likely to announce interest rate or RRR cuts in H2 to fuel an economic recovery due to blows stemming from the coronavirus pandemic and amid external uncertainties. (Global Times)

China's Global Times tweeted that the US is now unilaterally pushing decoupling with China and warned that in the post-pandemic world, it might find it is decoupling with the rest of the world citing a Chinese expert. (Global Times)

China’s Securities regulator, in response to US proposals which would force Chinese Co’s to delist from US exchanges, says this would ‘weaken confidence’ in American Markets and politicises securities regulation. (Newswires)

US National Security Adviser O’Brien stated that the US government will likely impose economic sanctions on Hong Kong and China if China moves forward with national security law for Hong Kong. There were also separate reports that US announced it will include 33 Chinese firms and institutions to an economic blacklist for actions including assisting Beijing spy on the minority Uighur population or allegations of ties to China's military and WMDs. (Newswires/NY Times)

UK Conservative MPs have called for PM Johnson to speed up new legislation to make it more difficult for overseas SOEs, such as Chinese firms, to take over struggling UK companies. In other news, UK PM Johnson was reportedly planning to reduce Huawei’s involvement in UK 5G network within the next three years. (FT/Telegraph)

Japan is reportedly to lift the state of emergency declaration in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama and Hokkaido today. There were also comments from Japanese Economic Minister Nishimura that the emergency declaration is no longer needed in any of Japan's regions and the expert panel also agreed the state of emergency can be lifted for all areas. (Nikkei/Newswires)

Japan’s government is considering compiling a second supplementary budget valued more than JPY 100tln which will consist of JPY 60tln for interest loan scheme for businesses and JPY 27tln for other financial support measures. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said he has looked at the allegations regarding adviser Cummings who he said acted responsibly and legally, while he added that he understands his situation and thinks that many do, but also noted he gets why people may feel confused and offended. This follows news that his top adviser Cummings was reported to Durham Police regarding breaking lockdown rules and PM Johnson is said to face cabinet revolt for supporting Cummings regarding the lockdown breach. (The Sun)

UK Chancellor Sunak authorised a bailout plan to save strategically important companies in which the government will acquire stakes in important companies experiencing acute financial difficulties, in which he widened the capacity of the Treasury to handle bespoke bailouts of viable companies that have exhausted all options. (FT/Newswires) UK Gov’t is reportedly to ask employers to fund 20-30% of employees wages on the furlough scheme as of August alongside their national insurance contributions. (Times)

UK Home Secretary Patel said they are bringing in quarantine measures now to prevent a second wave and protect our gains, while the UK announced a 14-day quarantine for arrivals in the country to prevent imported cases of coronavirus with measures to begin on June 8th and be reviewed every 3 weeks. (Newswires)

UK government is said to be a in new disagreement with Brussels over delays in granting full diplomatic status to the EU’s representation in London. (FT)

Netherlands, Austria, Denmark and Sweden have tabled an alternative proposal for the EU recovery fund that would have a two year limit and provide loans, not grants. (FT)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was lacklustre with price action rangebound beneath the 100.00 level owing to the absence of key global markets at the start of the week with both London and New York closed, while the early optimism at the beginning of Asia trade also contributed the greenback’s lack of appeal. Nonetheless, its major counterparts failed to capitalize on this with EUR/USD subdued after it relinquished the 1.0900 handle to the downside and with GBP/USD restrained below 1.2200 as PM Johnson was said to face Cabinet revolt after supporting senior adviser Cummings who faced calls to resign after breaching the lockdown. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was choppy amid the uneventful greenback and lack of global FX participants, which also resulted to drab price action for antipodean currencies and follows the weakest CNY reference rate setting by the PBoC since early 2008.

Australia preliminary exports for April fell 12% M/M and imports fell 5% M/M. (Newswires)

New Zealand government was said to be mulling a national unemployment insurance program and to make temporary tax-free payments to those that lost their jobs due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Turkey raised the tax on individual FX purchases to 1.0% from 0.2% and increased the withholding tax on banks’ commercial paper to 15% from 10% as it seeks to raise more funds to help address the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures were pressured at the open and briefly fell below the USD 33.00/bbl level but then recovered amid the mostly positive tone in Asia, while the latest Baker Hughes rig count showed further declines in oil rigs and reports also noted that US production was declining at a faster than expected pace. Elsewhere gold prices were marginally lower amid the slight positive risk tone which also underpinned copper prices but with gains capped amid underperformance in its largest buyer China.

Baker Hughes (22/05): Total rigs -21 at 318; oil rigs -21 to 237; nat gas. unchanged at 79. (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC+ members must remain committed to production cuts despite signs oil demand is starting to recover, while he added that there are tentative signs of recovery and we believe the worst is behind us according to Energy Intel. (Twitter)

US oil output is reported to be declining faster than anticipated with production by May 20th said to be down by almost 20% or 2.3mln bpd, while further declines are expected for the year according to reports citing Genscape. (FT)

Russian President Putin ordered a bailout of the nation’s oil industry. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US administration officials reportedly held discussions on Friday about the possibility of conducting a nuclear test which would be the first test explosion since 1992. This was after some officials asserted the China and Russia are conducting low yield nuclear tests, although the meeting concluded without any agreement. (Washington Post)

US

The TPLEX bull-flattened to end the week as participants withdrew risk exposure ahead of the long weekend, rising US-China tensions over Hong Kong, and disappointing China growth/stimulus targets. By settlement, 2s unchanged at 0.17% and 30s -3bps at 1.37%. Yields made their lows overnight, alongside equity futures, on the tails of the lacklustre China deficit target and lack of concrete GDP target. However, as the US session came into the horizon, equity futures and yields began to climb back higher finding support from Fauci comments and after the US equity open, yields traded rangebound through till settlement. T-Note futures (M0) settled 3 ticks higher at 139-05.

NY Fed cut Treasuries/TIPS purchases to USD 20bln (prev. 30bln) for the upcoming week. (Newswires)

subject: Japanese Coincident Index (Mar F) 90.2 (Prev. 90.5)
Japanese Leading Index (Mar F) 84.7 (Prev. 83.8)

ASX 200 (+1.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.5%) traded positive with tech and energy front running the broad gains seen across Australia’s sectors, while sentiment in Tokyo was underpinned by expectations the state of emergency will be lifted today in all remaining areas including the capital and with the government reportedly considering compiling a new package mostly consisting of financial support to companies which would be funded by a second supplementary budget valued more than JPY 100tln. Hang Seng (-1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) lagged their regional peers with the mainland bourse choppy amid ongoing US-China tensions and with the Hong Kong benchmark extending on last Friday’s near-6% slump after thousands of protester rallied on Sunday against China’s national security law, while the protests were met heavy handed by the police which used pepper spray and a water cannon to disperse the crowd. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally lower amid gains in Japanese stocks but with downside stemmed by the BoJ ‘s presence in the market for nearly JPY 1.1tln of JGBs mostly concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities.

subject: Germany coronavirus cases rose by 289 to 178,570 and death toll rose by 10 to 8,257 according to RKI Health Institute
New Zealand PM Ardern said rasing limit on social gatherings to 100 people effective May 29th and will consider moving to alert level 1 no later than June 22nd
OJI Holdings (3861 JT) FY net JPY 58.2bln vs. Prev. JPY 52.0bln Y/Y
Shimizu (1803 JT) FY net JPY 98.9bln vs. Prev. JPY 99.7bln Y/Y
Japanese Finance Minister Aso says expects unemployment rate to go up a little in May and notes that the bottom has not fallen out of Japan's economy
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia-Pac begins the week mostly higher, although Hong Kong lagged after protests resumed and holiday conditions kept FX drab
content:
Asia equity markets began the week mostly higher following last Friday’s recovery on Wall St. where the US major indices gradually clawed back opening losses after encouraging comments from NIH’s Fauci and US plans for large Phase 2 trials spurred vaccine-related optimism. ASX 200 (+1.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) are higher with tech and energy front running the broad gains seen across Australia’s sectors, while sentiment in Tokyo is underpinned by expectations the state of emergency will be lifted today in all remaining areas including the capital and with the government reportedly considering compiling a new package mostly consisting of financial support to companies which would be funded by a second supplementary budget valued more than JPY 100tln. Hang Seng (-1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) lag their regional peers with the mainland bourse choppy amid ongoing US-China tensions and with the Hong Kong benchmark extending on last Friday’s near-6% slump after thousands of protester rallied on Sunday against China’s national security law which was met heavy handed by the police which used pepper spray and a water cannon to disperse the crowd.

In FX markets, the DXY is lacklustre with price action rangebound beneath the 100.00 level owing to the absence of key global markets at the start of the week with both London and New York shut in observance of the Spring Bank Holiday and Memorial Day respectively, while the early optimism at the beginning of Asia trade also contributed the greenback’s lack of appeal. Nonetheless, its major counterparts failed to capitalize on this with EUR/USD subdued after it relinquished the 1.0900 handle to the downside and with GBP/USD restrained below 1.2200 as PM Johnson is said to face Cabinet revolt after supporting senior adviser Cummings who faced calls to resign after breaching the lockdown. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is choppy amid the uneventful greenback and lack of global FX participants, which has also resulted to drab price action for antipodean currencies and follows the weakest CNY reference rate setting by the PBoC since early 2008.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are marginally lower amid gains in Japanese stocks but with downside stemmed by the BoJ ‘s presence in the market for nearly JPY 1.1tln of JGBs mostly concentrated in 1yr-10yr maturities.

subject: Kia Motors (000270 KS) will further extend its Gwangju output halt in South Korea,  according to Yonhap
US President Trump tweets schools in our country should be opened ASAP and that much very good information is now available

China State Council Research Office Director Huang said there was intense debate on whether to drop the GDP target for this year or not and that final decision was made to free local governments from burden of a numeric target....
content: Says... and to encourage them to focus on protecting jobs, livelihoods and small businesses.

subject: Japanese Economic Minister Nishimura says expert panel agrees state of emergency can be lifted for all areas of Japan
Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga says new coronavirus cases have fallen significantly

Apple (AAPL) could launch augmented reality glasses in H2 2021, while it was also reported that LG Innotek (011070 KS), O-film and Sharp (6753 JT) were awarded camera module orders for new iPhones, according to DigiTimes
Fast Retailing (9983 JT) is planning to reopen 50 Uniqlo stores this week
Australia preliminary exports for April fell 12% M/M and imports fell 5% M/M
RBA skips offering to purchase bonds again today
PBoC sets USD/CNY mid-point at 7.1209 vs. Exp. 7.1205 (Prev. 7.0939)
analysis_details: • This represents the weakest fix since February 2008.

subject: PBoC skips open market operations and are net neutral on the day
PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: Hong Kong protests resumed due to China's national security law
content:
China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co. (000758 CH) - Co. drops plan to acquire assets after its proposal was rejected by shareholders. (Newswires)

Citic Resources (1205 HK) - Co. issued a profit warning in which it sees a net loss for the 6-month period to June. (Newswires)

Financials - PBoC article suggested that Chinese banks could report flat or declining profits for this year due to impact from the coronavirus. (Newswires)

 

Other News

Chinese President Xi said the country’s economy will prove resilient in the long term and that it will stand on the right side of history amid the rise of protectionism. There were also separate comments from the NDRC that it expects domestic consumption to show signs of an improvement this month as new forms of consumption such as e-commerce are encouraged. (SCMP/Newswires) 

China’s Global Times noted that Chinese experts predict the PBoC is highly likely to announce interest rate or RRR cuts in H2 to fuel an economic recovery due to blows stemming from the coronavirus pandemic and amid external uncertainties. (Global Times)

UK Conservative MPs have called for PM Johnson to speed up new legislation to make it more difficult for overseas SOEs, such as Chinese firms, to take over struggling UK companies. In other news, UK PM Johnson was reportedly planning to reduce Huawei’s involvement in UK 5G network. (FT/Telegraph)

 

Hong Kong/Tensions

Protests in Hong Kong resumed as thousands rallied to protest against China’s national security law, in which police used tear gas, pepper spray and water cannon on the crowds. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said they are to fully co-operate with China to enact the National Security law as soon as possible and it was also reported that the Hong Kong government stated that China's Parliamentary decision on the national security law will not affect the rights and freedoms of Hong Kong citizens. (Newswires)

Chinese Foreign Ministry said that it will fight back if the US attempts to oppress them. In other news, a Chinese NPC official said as far as they know, the Hong Kong legislation is ready which will be passed in the next meeting of the NPC Standing Committee and could be passed into law after resolutions are voted for on May 28th. Furthermore, China Foreign Minister Wang said political virus is spreading in US along with the coronavirus and that US and China should look for ways to avoid a new cold war. (Newswires/Global Times)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US condemns China’s proposal to unilaterally and arbitrarily impose national security legislation on Hong Kong, while he added that China’s decision to bypass the HK legislature would be the ‘death knell’ for Hong Kong’s autonomy proposed under agreement. Pompeo also suggested the US could simply disconnect from Australia if the Victoria state government’s agreed involvement in China’s Belt and Road initiative threatens telecommunication security. However, US Ambassador to Australia later downplayed the comments and said they were in response to a "very remote hypothetical" and that the US has "absolute confidence" in Australia's ability to handle the issue. (Newswires)

US National Security Adviser O’Brien stated that the US government will likely impose economic sanctions on Hong Kong and China if China moves forward with national security law for Hong Kong. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department added 9 Chinese entities to its Entities List related to human rights abuses, while it was also reported that the US is to add 33 Chinese firms and institutions to an economic blacklist for actions including assisting with Chinese military activities. (Newswires/Twitter)
